oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Death of Colonel Robert Rennie scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Death of Colonel Rennie," shows wounded British officer slumping forward. Behind him are his men. Armed Americans are firing at him from front. Decorative border around image. Black and white version also available. From John Frost and W. Croome, "Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson" (1848). Design by William Croome.

Colonel Robert Rennie, leading British infantrymen and fusiliers, died in an assault on Americans at the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815). The Treaty of Ghent, signed two weeks earlier, ended the War of 1812. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither the British nor Americans knew the war was over.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Campaigns & battles; Daggers & swords; Clothing & dress; Cotton
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Downes, J.
